_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
Brandon Shores Aqueous Ammonia RMP
2006 Update

Facility Overview

The Brandon Shores Power Plant, owned and operated by Constellation Power Source Generation (CPSG), is located near Baltimore, Maryland in northern Anne Arundel County.  It is a fossil fueled electric generating facility consisting of two 650 megawatt coal fired units.  To improve air quality and comply with Maryland Clean Air requirements, pollution control technology called selective catalytic reduction (SCR) was installed in 2001 to reduce NOx (nitrogen oxides) emissions by 90%. 

SCRs use ammonia to react with the NOx in the combustion gas to form harmless nitrogen gas and water.  Because safety of CPSG employees and the surrounding community is of utmost concern to CPSG, Brandon Shores uses urea technology to generate ammonia for the SCR on as as needed bases.   Urea is a less hazardous solid that can react to form ammonia on-site to reduce transportation risks and to minimize on-site quantities of ammonia.   Since the urea technology had not been fully proven when the SCR was under design and construction, Brandon Shores also has a 30% aqueous ammonia system that is available as a back-up system incase the urea system is out of service due to operational problems or for maintenance.   The SCR ammonia system is kept essentially empty unless it must be used due to urea system problems.  

The SCR aqueous ammonia system consists of three 18,000-gallon storage tanks surrounded by a dike wall.  
The aqueous ammonia is pumped from the storage tanks to a vaporizer.  The vaporizer uses steam to heat the ammonia solution converting it into a vapor.   The ammonia vapor is mixed with air and injected into the SCR.  The ammonia vapor reacts with the NOx in the presence of the catalyst to form harmless nitrogen gas and water vapor.  

Safety features include:
? Diked/protected storage and unloading areas. 
? Remote controlled shut off valves at the storage tanks.
? Level/pressure/temperatu

re alarms.
? Extra strong design 
? Surveillance camera for 24 hour observation.
? Ammonia monitors around the perimeter.
? Water cannons for vapor suppression.

Brandon Shores has another 30% aqueous ammonia tank that supplies ammonia for pH control of the boiler feedwater (cycle chemistry process).  This tank has a capacity of 5000 gallons.  It is surrounded by a dike that drains directly into a 70,000 gallon sump located under the storage tank.  

Release Prevention Policies

CPSG believes that safety and health are our highest value and all injuries and most illnesses are preventable.  Operating safely, with constant focus on accident prevention and occupational health processes, is the most efficient way to manage our business.  It is the best way to safeguard our employees and the communities in which we are located.  Our safety concern extends not only to that of our fellow employees but also to our families, customers, contractors, visitors, and communities in which we operate.  

CPSG utilizes effective accident prevention strategies such as safety in engineering design, training, behavior-based initiatives, and administrative controls to safeguard against workplace hazards.  We have a comprehensive accidental release prevention program based on the following key elements:
? Hazard review ? A detailed hazard analysis was performed identifying risks and recommendations for reducing the potential for and impact of releases.   All design recommendations have been incorporated.   
? Designing a safe facility ? CPSG elected to use urea technology to generate ammonia on-site for the SCR as needed to minimize on-site inventory and transportation risk.  The regulated SCR ammonia process is used only as a back up and it uses 30% aqueous ammonia which is inherently safer than anhydrous ammonia, a commonly used alternative.  All applicable codes and standards were incorporated into the design.   On-site inventory was minimized and safety features were incorporated tha

t go beyond industry standards including the remote controlled tank isolation valves, ammonia monitors, and surveillance camera.  
? Operating procedures ? Standard operating procedures and safe work practices are strictly followed.  
? Training ? All CPSG technicians are qualified on applicable operating and maintenance procedures, safe work practices, and emergency response procedures.  A qualified emergency response HAZMAT team is present on site at all times.  The drivers of the ammonia trucks are trained on the plant specific unloading and emergency response procedures. 
? Preventive maintenance ? A preventive maintenance and inspection program has been developed to ensure the ongoing mechanical integrity of the system.
? Change management ? Change management procedures have been implemented to ensure proper materials of construction, safety evaluation, and updating of operating/maintenance procedures.  

Accident History

The Brandon Shores facility has never experienced a reportable release or accident associated with the storage or use of 30% aqueous ammonia.  

Emergency Response Program 

Brandon Shores has a detailed Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan that includes specific emergency response procedures, procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies, and first aid and emergency medical treatment information for ammonia exposure.  The emergency response procedures have been provided to the local emergency planning committee (LEPC) for distribution to the local emergency planning and response organizations as needed.   The local fire department has toured the facility many times and a comprehensive tour was provided for all local emergency response agencies on October 13, 2005.

All plant personnel are trained on emergency response procedures.  A fully qualified HAZMAT response team is on-site at all times.  Emergency response drills are performed quarterly.

Planned Changes to improve safety 

Brandon Shores significantly

improved the safety of the ammonia feed system for the SCR since submittal of the original RMP in 2001 by installing and operating a urea based system that generates ammonia as needed.  This eliminated the need for routine on-site storage and transportation of ammonia to the site.  Future planned safety improvements include painting and updating the contents of the ammonia safety equipment locker.
